comment_text.mn152:1.2: The names here are spelled gajaṅgalā and suveḷuvana, but I keep consistency with AN 10.28, where a nun residing at this town gives a penetrative discourse to the townsfolk. In the Vinaya it is mentioned as the easternmost point of the “middle country”, just beyond which lay Mahāsāla (Kd 5:13.12.2). The Milindapañha says it was a brahmin village on the slopes of the Himalayas where its main protagonist, the monk Nāgasena, was born (Mil 2:22.3). Assuming both these are the same place, we might look somewhere near Darjeeling for this town. In any case, it represents the furthest east that the Buddha taught. It is sometimes identified with 羯蠅揭羅 mentioned by Xuang Zang, but that has been located near Agra south of Sāvatthī.
comment_text.mn152:2.1: A brahmin teacher named Pārāsariya (also spelled Pārāpariya or Pārāsiviya) features in Ja 222 and Ja 353 as one who warns that doing evil will lead to regret. The three similarly-named monks in the Theragāthā (Thag 1.116, Thag 16.2, Thag 16.10) share the same clan name (Sanskrit Pārāśarya). These are descendants of the great sage Parāśara Śāktya, who is mentioned in Rig Veda 7.1.18 alongside Śatayātu, Vasiṣṭha; his prayers to Agni are recorded at Rig Veda 1.65–73, and to Soma at 9.97.31–44.
comment_text.mn152:2.6: This is perhaps a distorted reference to certain Upaniṣadic teachings that speak of the undifferentiated state of divinity that contains the potential for the faculties of seeing, etc. See DN 29:16.13 and note there. Perhaps, too, it refers to the notion that in deep sleep the senses are withdrawn into the “space of the heart” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.17).
comment_text.mn152:2.10: This teaching is not about deep meditation, where the senses can be in a state of abeyance, but about how we relate to the experience of the senses.
comment_text.mn152:4.10: The Buddha gives a series of similes, each one appropriate to the specific sense.
comment_text.mn152:4.12: Bearing in mind that the word for “faculty”, indriya, has the sense of “potential”, this phrase emphasizes that the “restraint” of the senses is also the way to “develop” them to their fullest.
comment_text.mn152:10.1: This is at least a stream-enterer; they still react to sense experiences that are agreeable or disagreeable, but they understand that they lead to suffering and train themselves to be freed..
comment_text.mn152:11-15.1: This is the arahant. They still experience sense stimulation as pleasant, etc., but without reacting.
comment_text.mn152:11-15.3: Here this ability is fully mastered. It is taught to those in training as a practice at AN 5.144.
comment_text.mn152:18.2: The Majjhima Nikāya ends with the Buddha encouraging the archetypal student of the suttas, Ānanda, to develop meditation.

translation_text.mn152:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kajaṅgalā in a bamboo grove.
translation_text.mn152:2.1: Then the student Uttara, a pupil of the brahmin Pārāsariya, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn152:2.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn152:2.3: “Uttara, does Pārāsariya teach his disciples the development of the faculties?”
translation_text.mn152:2.6: “Worthy Gotama, it’s when the eye sees no sight and the ear hears no sound.
translation_text.mn152:2.7: That’s how Pārāsariya teaches his disciples the development of the faculties.”
translation_text.mn152:2.8: “In that case, Uttara, a blind person and a deaf person will have developed faculties
translation_text.mn152:2.10: For a blind person sees no sight with the eye and a deaf person hears no sound with the ear.”
translation_text.mn152:2.11: When he said this, Uttara sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
translation_text.mn152:3.1: Knowing this, the Buddha addressed Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.mn152:3.2: “Ānanda, the development of the faculties taught by Pārāsariya is quite different from the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One.”
translation_text.mn152:3.3: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One.
translation_text.mn152:3.4: Let the Buddha teach the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
translation_text.mn152:3.5: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn152:4.1: “And how, Ānanda, is there the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One?
translation_text.mn152:4.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, in them arises what is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable.
translation_text.mn152:4.4: ‘What is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable have arisen in me.
translation_text.mn152:4.5: That’s conditioned, crude, and dependently originated.
translation_text.mn152:4.6: But this is peaceful and sublime, namely
translation_text.mn152:4.8: Then the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease,
translation_text.mn152:4.10: It’s like how a person with clear eyes might open their eyes then shut them; or might shut their eyes then open them.
translation_text.mn152:4.11: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.
translation_text.mn152:4.12: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding sights known by the eye.

translation_text.mn152:9.9: It’s like how a strong person could let two or three drops of water fall onto an iron cauldron that had been heated all day.
translation_text.mn152:9.10: The drops would be slow to fall, but they’d quickly dry up and evaporate.
translation_text.mn152:9.11: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.
translation_text.mn152:9.12: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding ideas known by the mind.
translation_text.mn152:9.13: That’s how there is the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One.
translation_text.mn152:10.1: And how are they a practicing trainee?
translation_text.mn152:10.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.
translation_text.mn152:10.3: They are horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.
translation_text.mn152:10.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn152:10.5: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn152:10.6: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn152:10.7: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn152:10.8: When they know a thought with their mind, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.
translation_text.mn152:10.9: They are horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.
translation_text.mn152:10.10: That’s how they are a practicing trainee.
translation_text.mn152:11-15.1: And how are they a noble one with developed faculties?
translation_text.mn152:11-15.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.
translation_text.mn152:11-15.3: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:11-15.4: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:11-15.5: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:11-15.6: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive and the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:11-15.7: If they wish: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, shunning both the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:16.1: When they hear a sound with their ear …
translation_text.mn152:16.2: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn152:16.3: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn152:16.4: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn152:16.5: When they know a thought with their mind, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.
translation_text.mn152:16.6: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:16.7: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:16.8: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:16.9: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive and the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:16.10: If they wish: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, shunning both the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.mn152:16.11: That’s how they are a noble one with developed faculties.
translation_text.mn152:17.1: So, Ānanda, I have taught the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One, I have taught the practicing trainee, and I have taught the noble one with developed faculties.
translation_text.mn152:18.1: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
translation_text.mn152:18.2: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
translation_text.mn152:18.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn152:18.4: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
